title: How many deaths attributed to COVID-19 in the US will be reported for the week ending 3 July﻿ 2021?
preds: 150 +172 + 273 = 595.  2000 (bottom of bin 3) - 595 = 1405 1405 / 4 days left = 351.25 deaths/day from here on out.    I was wrong before the correct date that last had > 350 deaths was June 10.  More importantly, imo, the last day with > 350 deaths as a 7 day moving average was June 8.  Current 7 day MA is 256.
161+168 = 329.  2000-329/5 = 334.2 deaths/day from here on out. The last time there were > 334 deaths in a day was June 6.
Deaths are still above 2000 and and actually ticked up last week. Hedging s little bit with a higher probability above 2000

I define the 7-day CFR = 7-day average of deaths/day today / 7-day average of cases/day 3 weeks ago.
The 7-day CFR on July 3 would (coincidentally) need to be <=1.00% for deaths to be <1k for this forecast, and would need to be >=2.00% for deaths to be >2k.
I expect the 7-day CFR to fall back to <2.0% on June 28, as cases 3 weeks before emerge out of a relative dip. If it doesn't, I'll revise my forecast. Also, it looks possible that deaths will decline further again.
Date, 7-day CFR

6/15, 1.41%
6/16, 1.41%
6/17, 1.35%
6/18, 1.37%
6/19, 1.36%
6/20, 1.40%
6/21, 1.72% 
6/22, 1.77%
6/23, 1.85%
6/24, 2.05%
6/25, 2.06%
6/26, 1.99%
6/27, 2.01%
6/28, 1.73%! Back down below 2.00%. Done.

Trend line would put us at 1473 based in 43 recent data points.  The root mean error was 372, so more than one standard deviation from the trend to be above 2000. No guarantee the trend will continue, but it’s been stable for a few weeks now. Delta variant is still low enough not to like break the trend this week.
Latest increase in deaths doesn't really make sense to me but bumping up over 2k just in case.

There is a real risk that deaths will be >2,000. Going with the crowd forecast for now.
7-day average of cases/day for June 12 is 14,315.
I define the 7-day CFR = 7-day average of deaths/day today / 7-day average of cases/day 3 weeks ago.
The 7-day CFR would need to be <=1.00% for deaths to be <1k, and would need to be >=2.0% for deaths to be >2k.
The 7-day CFR was around 1.0% or below for a 2-week period from 5/3 to 5/16. Since 5/20, it has been above 1.10%. Since 5/27, it has been above 1.2%, ranging as high as 1.56%. 9 days left in the forecast.
Recent values:
Date, 7-day CFR
6/14, 1.39%
6/15, 1.41%
6/16, 1.41%
6/17, 1.35%
6/18, 1.37%
6/19, 1.36%
6/20, 1.40%
6/21, 1.72% (Extremely high! Corresponding to a dip in the 7-day average of cases on 5/31 and a slight increase in deaths; the 7-day average of cases/day on June 12 is, if anything, slightly higher than expected)
6/22, 1.77% (Cases still in a dip.) 
6/23, 1.88% (And higher....)
6/24, 2.09% (Using NYT data available early. Unprecedented in data since mid April!)
I still expect the CFR will fall as cases go back to trend, but this is less clear. Also, I'll note that deaths <1000 or >3000 are extremely, extremely unlikely. To see deaths <1000 would require a fall in the CFR from 2.09% on 6/24 to <1.00% on 7/3. There has been no fall of that absolute or relative magnitude in such a short period of time since June 2020, when testing was just getting going. Similarly, seeing deaths >3000 would require a rise in the CFR from 2.09% on 6/24 to >3.00% on 7/3. A rise of that absolute or relative magnitude in such a short period of time has also not been seen since June 2020 - and moreover, a value > 3.0% has not been seen since June 2020 and was an artifact of low testing rates back then. It's not inconceivable that Delta or some subsequent variant could turn out to be much more deadly than Alpha, but right now, nearly all deaths are from Alpha and other strains. A CFR > 3.0% by July 3 is not a realistic possibility.
This person has a nice graph of the CFR over time (I'm not sure exactly how he calculates it, but it looks similar to my graph over the time since I've been looking at it):
https://twitter.com/_stah/status/1408352771020107779/photo/2 Update:
Date, 7-day CFR
6/25, 2.16%
6/26, 2.10%
Boost up if trend continues next few days.

Updating my forecast. Thanks to @belikewater who pointed out my blunder at first. Wrongly interpreted the data on the Our World in Data dataset.
Basically the trend is going downward steadily but slowly. Also thanks for pointing out something I did not see at first, deaths occur on average 3 weeks from the infection date so the lifting of social distancing and mask wearing measures will probably not reflect on higher numbers of new deaths for the week ending July 3rd.
Freestyle forecast. Adjust back to consensus if next couple/few days continue to drop as widely expected.

Should have updated faster. We're tracking right into middle of 1000 - 2000 based on CFR and latest case counts as others have talked about. I'm giving some upside to the low-end with the possibility of CFRs dropping further because so many elderly are vaccinated still.

The US is already averaging less than 1,000 deaths attributed to COVID, per week, since April. 
There is a very small chance that with the lifting of sanitary restrictions, unvaccinated people might get the disease and present a spike in death statistics by the end of June.
Even considering the new Delta variant, which seems to be more aggressive and deadlier, the forecast for deaths will not likely get higher in the US because the vaccines are still effective against it. (https://www.theguardian.com/world/2021/jun/15/the-covid-delta-variant-how-effective-are-the-vaccines).
Most of people at risk (senior citizens) present higher ratios of vaccinations (https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/70/wr/mm7023e2.htm) and the average reproduction rate of the virus below 0.8 for the last month, see our world in data for the US data set: https://covid.ourworldindata.org/data/owid-covid-data.xlsx
Also, on the data set mentioned above the rate of new vaccinations per day is still averaging above 1 million in the US, so the data looks good to project fewer than 1,000 deaths on the week between June 26 and July 3.
The crowd forecast seems pretty concentrated in a narrow window, I'm putting some chips on death rate coming down less slowly as you have a chunk of the population that continues to be exposed.
Revising as I think I poorly estimated the amount of time / the trend in deaths.

Thresholds 
Bin 2 1k = 143 per day 
Bin 3 2k = 285 per day
Bin 4 3k = 429 per day Current numbers around 330ish.  Slow steady decrease. 3 weeks to go.  10-20pc drop per week. 20pc drop per week over next 3 weeks gets us to 240, so upping likelihood of bin 2

Rt going up and hospital admissions going down. This pattern usually entails a drop in deaths to come. However, always that tendency to spike up. And when cases spike up, the proportion of deaths may increase. Otherwise, I agree with consensus that 1k to 2k is likely if rate continues the same.

Let the baseline be the crowd forecast: 80% 1k-2k and 20% 2k-3k The 7 day moving average of deaths/day is currently sitting at 292 and has been sitting in that to 340ish range for almost 2 weeks (plateau?) Less than 1000/7 = 143 deaths/day is the lowest by 40 ever which seems nearly impossible save a miraculous improvement over the next two weeks.   2000/7 = 285 deaths per day is on par with the lower end of the 7 day moving average.  Should deaths continue decreasing, I'd say this would be slightly more than 50% likely and 7 day moving avg for hospitalizations have been decreasing WoW.   With all this in mind, I'm seeing odds of 2-3k as higher than the baseline but will lean slightly towards a continuation of decreasing deaths (ie. 1-2k)
Still expecting 1,600-1,900, but having been stung last month I’m not quite 100% convinced of this yet

7-day average of cases/day for June 12 is 14,315. 
I define the 7-day CFR = 7-day average of deaths/day today / 7-day average of cases/day 3 weeks ago.
The 7-day CFR would need to be <=1.00% for deaths to be <1k, and would need to be >=2.0% for deaths to be >2k.
The 7-day CFR was around 1.0% or below for a 2-week period from 5/3 to 5/16. Since 5/20, it has been above 1.10%. Since 5/27, it has been above 1.2%, ranging as high as 1.56%. It's currently at 1.44%. 19 days left in the forecast.

6/23, 1.88% !!!! (I'm wondering whether we'll be in this high range until 6/28, when case numbers come back up towards a trend. If it doesn't come down on or by 6/28, then I will need to reassess and mourn my destroyed Brier score.)

Oops, false alarm about an uptick in hospitalizations. That was the UK. Could be headed here for next month, though.
Going back down to a lower chance for the third bin.
I'll hedge slightly higher against the outrageous possibility of a 7day CFR of 2.0% because there was supposedly just a big jump in hospitalizations. Need to investigate further.
Continues to fall. With time on I reduced chance of it rebounding

7-day average for June 12 is 14,315.
1000/7/14315 = 0.0100 => 1.00% CFR, possible but very unlikely.
2000/7/14315 = 0.0200 => 2.00% CFR, way over anything seen, even with spikes; not likely to see that radical of a change in just a few weeks, especially as the CFR has, if anything, continued a slow decrease in the UK. Plus, Delta is responsible for approx <10% cases as of June 12.

Preview of June 12 cases: about 18,490. So the 7-day average for June 12 will likely be ~14.1k.
2000/14.1k/7 = 0.020. The 7-day CFR on July 3 would need to be ~0.020 for deaths to exceed 2000. It is possible that the CFR will go up because of the Delta variant; however, so far, it has not gone up in the UK, so it doesn't seem likely that it will go up much here, if at all (probably because most of the most vulnerable are vaccinated.)
So, I really don't think >2k cases is possible, but having learned from last time, I won't set it to 0%.
<1k cases is possible, though. 1000/14.1k/7 = 0.010, i.e., a 7-day CFR of 1.0%. This is really unlikely but not completely out of the question. Also need to wait for today's final numbers to make a better assessment, and need to watch and wait.

Thresholds 
Bin 2 1k = 143 per day 
Bin 3 2k = 285 per day
Bin 4 3k = 429 per day Current numbers around 370sh.  Range 300-400 so still most likely bin 3
13k and a 7day CFR of 0.0119 is possible. 13k*7*0.0119 = 1083.

13k * 7 * 0.012 = 1092
13k * 7 * 0.011 = 1000
15k * 7 * 0.019 = 2000
Not likely <1000 but not impossible. Also not likely >2k. 7day cases on June 12 will probably be <15k, and the CFR would have to rise to never before seen levels over the next few weeks to reach >2000.

Latest report was 1743, but that was a sharp drop from the previous period. The general trend is still down, so AI think we will be below 2000. Vaccination rates are falling, but cases have been declining recently, which will affect the deaths at the end of the month.  Might get an uptick due to delta variant or reporting issues.

The drop today is due to Alameda County, California, which found over 400 previously reported coronavirus deaths that they say were not caused by the disease. The JHU data shows a decline of 437 in that county today, resulting in a total of -20 deaths being reported in the US today (I assume that's just some minimum Our World in Data uses, it would have been a lot smaller if the full -437 deaths were counted). If I ignore Alameda County I'm coming up with 32 deaths for that day instead of -20. Still pretty low so that's good. Guess I'll have to account for the possibility in a temporary downward spike in deaths as well as upward. Our World in Data daily deaths showing -20 for today: https://ourworldindata.org/explorers/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=2021-05-04..latest&pickerSort=asc&pickerMetric=location&Metric=Confirmed+deaths&Interval=New+per+day&Relative+to+Population=false&Align+outbreaks=false&country=~USA Article about Alameda county reduction: https://oaklandside.org/2021/06/04/alameda-countys-new-covid-death-toll-is-25-lower-than-thought/ The JHU data and my numbers I used to find the anomaly: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/12UL4UJb6zqRJnOQMTaQyZYVgte1TtSDTJ97DlbKYlwo/edit?usp=sharing

We know that as deaths decrease there is some slowing down in the rate of decrease. Current rate would suggest below 1000 by 3rd July but flattening effect means it’s most likely to be between 1000 and 2000. High levels of vaccine hesitancy in certain areas + opening up effect = very low chance of below 1000.

Expecting a decline for two/three weeks matching prior cases trend, then allowing a flattening based on erratic CFR and potential delta case complications.
My best estimate is 1,650-1,975 but allowing a wider margin than usual.

The 7day CFR will likely be in the range 0.012 to 0.017 (going higher to account for the possibility that Delta will increase the CFR). If the CFR is 0.016, then we'd need to see <9k cases/day to see <1k deaths. To get to bin 3, we'd need to see a big increase in cases by June 12 and/or a big increase in the CFR.

Thresholds 
3k = 429 per day
2k = 285 per day
1k = 143 per day Current numbers around 420ish.  Range 350-400 so still most likely bin 2.  More likely to dry than increase.

The Delta variant is here.
20k cases/day on June 12 is plausible if cases start increasing here like they have in the UK.
A 7day CFR of 1.20% to 1.60% is likely based on the past few weeks.
17k * 7 * 0.0120 = 1428
17k * 7 * 0.0160 = 1904
17.86k * 7 * 0.0160 = 2000
16.81k * 7 * 0.0170 = 2000
15.87k * 7 * 0.0180 = 2000 (would mean that the7-day CFR is increasing above the level seen w/ ancestral strains w/o vaccination, b/c of Delta)
15.87k * 7 * 0.0090 = 1000
18.5k * 7 * 0.0145 = 1878
20k * 7 * 0.0120 = 1680
20k * 7 * 0.0160 = 2240
If the 7-day average of cases/day <15.87k on June 12, then the chance of >2000 deaths in the forecast period is just about zero. Need to watch what happens over the next few days.
For deaths to be <1000, then cases must be <15.87k on June 12, assuming that we would see a 7-day average CFR of no less than 0.09%; it's extremely unlikely to be that low. Also, spikes in reported deaths seem to happen more often than dips in reporting, except around major holidays.
So if the 7-day average of cases/day <15.87k on June 12, then the probability of bin 3 will be almost 0 (unless we start to see wild increases in the CFR as the month goes on). If the 7-day average of cases/day >15.87k on June 12, then the probability of bin 1 will be 0.

Maintaining my forecast, I think the latest increase is mostly a reporting thing. Many states did not report on memorial day so the day after (June 1st) was higher than normal, and now June 1st is pushing up the weekly average since the lower memorial day dropped off the weekly average. If I'm correct we should see it fall back down tomorrow. Hoping that's all it is!

Reverting to initial forecast. While 2,000+ is now more credible, I still think the range is more likely to be nearer 1,500-1,900. 
I'm allowing a wider margin than usual after past experience.

Cases may be increasing. The delta variant has arrived. Updating scenarios I'm considering:
Worst-case scenario: 7-day average of cases/day on June 12 is 20k (increasing), and the "7-day CFR" is 1.7% (what was seen with ancestral strains before vaccinations). Deaths for the week ending July 3 = 20k * 7 * 0.017 = 2380.
Best-case scenario: 9k * 7 * 0.009 = 567
More plausible scenario: 15k * 7 * 0.0145 = 1523
If we say the 7-day CFR won't go below 1.2%, because it hasn't since May 25 (but it's still possible), then the 7-day average of cases on June 12 would need to be <11.9k for deaths to stay <1000. That's still possible but is looking less likely.
Because cases may be growing and more deadly variants are spreading, I'm adding a substantial possibility of the third bin. I'm not sure what's going on with cases right now, beyond the fact that it's Air-Conditioning Season in the South and Southwest, and the Delta variant (first seen in India, and increases the risk of hospitalization by 2.57x compared to the Alpha strain (first found in the UK)) is headed towards becoming dominant in the US by sometime in July. That could increase the CFR beyond my worst case scenario, because most deaths are in unvaccinated people; the effects of the Delta strain are just starting to be felt. However, it's not clear what the CFR of the Delta variant is at this point; some data suggest that the Delta CFR might be 2x that of ancestral strains. Also, we have too few data at this point to know the efficacy of different vaccines in protecting from death due to infection with the Delta variant, although it is likely high (although 1 dose appears to offer only ~30% protection from symptomatic infection). Need to watch closely.
https://twitter.com/joaquinlife/status/1402016011142909967
Also note that Rt for the Delta variant has been estimated at 1.64 (i.e., spreading much faster than Covid spread in any state in the US last winter) in the UK a month ago. While >50% of the population has had at least one vaccine dose, a substantial fraction of the population still has no immunity. So, even though we're heading into summer in the US, we could still see substantial spread of the Delta variant, and consequently an increase in cases and in the CFR.
https://twitter.com/chrischirp/status/1400390032079347712
I think the consensus aid is right, but I think it's underestimating bin 3.

Same rationale and opinion but without a couple of errors in calculations, lol - new expected range approx 1,100-1,800, with a bias towards the lower end.
Expecting deaths to start tracking the drop in case rates (over prior three weeks) more closely, with potential for fluctuations. CFR could move around if case rates rise, at least during this window.

Deaths lag cases by 3 weeks.
Worst case scenario: 7-day average of cases/day on June 12 is 16k (it's currently 14.6k, so that would mean cases are increasing), and the "7-day CFR" is 1.7% (no effect of vaccination). Deaths for the week ending July 3 = 16k * 7 * 0.017 = 1904. I don't see how deaths could get higher than that. Even in the wild ride of the past few weeks, the "7-day CFR" never got as high as 1.6%. So I believe bins 3 and up are out.
Best case scenario: 7-day average of cases/day on June 12 is 7k (unlikely that low), and the 7-day CFR is 0.9% (we've never seen a 7-day CFR that low). Then deaths for the week ending July 3 = 7k * 7 * 0.009 = 441.
I think the 7-day CFR will trend to between 1.2% and 1.3%, although volatility is high, inside a range of 0.9% to 1.6%.
One possible scenario: 11k * 7 * 0.013 = 1001
Another possible scenario: 9k * 7 * 0.012 = 756
It really depends where you think cases will be on June 12 and the CFR on July 3. As we've seen, deaths and, correspondingly, the 7-day CFR can be quite volatile. This forecast could turn out to be very close, like the last one. Because of the volatility, I'll forecast close to 50:50 for now.

I've tried a few approaches, and while my full range of outcomes is 1,200-2,200 I'm leaning towards 1,600-1,800 with a greater risk on the upside. Summary view is that deaths should track recent cases more closely now (lag-allowing) than last month, with a steady CFR, and if cases change markedly the lag will allow death rates to continue falling (as they have previously) towards the close, even if the rate slows. 
Forecast: 1,500-1,850, but currently allowing ~300 either side

Going by a roughly 3 week lag in the deaths data from the case data the downward trend should continue. If it drops the same amount over the next month that it did this month that would be 1,800 cases, so around 1,200 on July 3. It seems like deaths have been heading down at a slower rate than cases, but I'm wondering if it matches up better if you just ignore the bump upward in cases that happened in April. I'm keeping a decently wide distribution because it's possible deaths don't track cases as much as they used to due to vaccinated and unvaccinated populations. And of course leaving some room for possible backdating around resolution time. A chart with cases and deaths scaled to compare the trajectory of each is here: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1tY8FgmbrvY6a0JI7Fm0QiabMhUpia6eRIC3ve1Oy-wY/edit?usp=sharing
With 15,000 new admissions I expect that about 10% deaths.  I expect new variants with higher mortality
Putting more eggs in the smaller baskets.

Last 7 days was 3,762 deaths. It's dropping a lot as vaccination increases + folks have had COVID. The drop has had a few periods of time of flatlining, but if you look at countries like UK and Israel it seems likely death counts will drop even faster once the number of vaccinated people continues to increase. You have a hangover from cases that were acquired prior to wider vaccination efforts.  Given that, I leave just 17% chance of death count being same or higher than now, with almost all of that assuming it hovers around this level. This leaves open the chance of a period of stagnation in drop.  If we reduce in volume same percentage in next month as we did this month we'd get to 2000-3000, with tapered likelihood of the other ones.
This was not a good forecast.
